title: El Salvador at the Olympics
text:
<a href="El%20Salvador">El Salvador</a> first competed in the <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a> at the <a href="1968%20Summer%20Olympics">1968 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Mexico%20City">Mexico City</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>. It has participated in every <a href="Summer%20Olympic%20Games">Games of the Olympiad</a> since that time, excluding those held in <a href="1976%20Summer%20Olympics">1976</a> and <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics">1980</a>, when the nation joined the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics%20boycott">American-led boycott</a> in protest of the <a href="Soviet%20invasion%20of%20Afghanistan">Soviet invasion of Afghanistan</a>. They have never competed in the <a href="Olympic%20Winter%20Games">Olympic Winter Games</a>. El Salvador has not earned a medal at any Olympic Games.
Athletes from El Salvador have represented their nation in 13 sports. A total of 118 Salvadorian athletes have competed at the Olympic Games. <a href="Swimming%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">Swimming</a> (28 athletes) and <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%20Summer%20Olympics">athletics</a> (27 athletes) have fetched the most participation from El Salvador.
The Comité Olímpico de El Salvador was created in 1925 and recognized by the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> in 1938.
Summer Olympic Games.
1968 Mexico City.
Though the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> recognized <a href="El%20Salvador">El Salvador</a>'s <a href="National%20Olympic%20Committee">National Olympic Committee</a> (Comité Olímpico de El Salvador) in 1938, the nation's first <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a> participation did not occur until the <a href="1968%20Summer%20Olympics">1968 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Mexico%20City">Mexico City</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>. The contingent of 60 athletes marked the largest in El Salvador's Olympic participation. Salvadorian athletes competed in seven sports (athletics, cycling, football, sailing, shooting, swimming, and weightlifting) but won no medals. Both the all-time youngest and oldest Olympic participants from El Salvador competed at these games. Swimmer <a href="Rub%C3%A9n%20Guerrero">Rubén Guerrero</a> (13 years, 351 days) swam in five events: the Men's 400 meters Freestyle, 1,500 meters Freestyle, 4 × 100 meters Freestyle Relay, 100 meters Butterfly, and 200 meters Individual Medley. <a href="Roberto%20Soundy">Roberto Soundy</a> (68 years, 229 days) finished 54th in the Mixed Trap Shooting event. Swimmer <a href="Salvador%20Vilanova">Salvador Vilanova</a> was selected to carry his nation's flag during the opening ceremony.
1972 Munich.
El Salvador's presence was much reduced when the nation sent only 11 athletes to the <a href="1972%20Summer%20Olympics">1972 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Munich">Munich</a>, <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>. These athletes competed in swimming and shooting events, marking the lowest number of contested sports in El Salvador's Olympic history. Swimmer <a href="Salvador%20Vilanova">Salvador Vilanova</a> was once again selected to carry his nation's flag during the opening ceremony.
1984 Los Angeles.
No athletes were sent to the <a href="1976%20Summer%20Olympics">1976 Summer Olympics</a>, and El Salvador took part in the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics%20boycott">boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics</a>.
El Salvador returned to Olympic competition by sending ten athletes to participate in the <a href="1984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. El Salvador competed in athletics, judo, swimming, shooting, and wrestling. Long-distance runner <a href="Kriscia%20Garc%C3%ADa">Kriscia García</a> was chosen to carry her nation's flag during the opening ceremony.
1988 Seoul.
Six athletes were sent to compete at the <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Seoul">Seoul</a>, <a href="South%20Korea">South Korea</a>. Salvadorian athletes competed in athletics, boxing, judo, and wrestling. Wrestler <a href="Gustavo%20Manzur">Gustavo Manzur</a> was chosen to carry his nation's flag during the opening ceremony.
1992 Barcelona.
El Salvador sent its smallest-ever contingent of athletes to the <a href="1992%20Summer%20Olympics">1992 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a>. Four athletes participated in athletics, judo, and swimming. Swimmer <a href="Mar%C3%ADa%20Jos%C3%A9%20Marenco">María José Marenco</a> was selected to carry her nation's flag during the opening ceremony.
1996 Atlanta.
Eight Salvadorian athletes competed in the <a href="1996%20Summer%20Olympics">1996 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Atlanta">Atlanta</a>, <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. They competed in five events: athletics, judo, swimming, cycling, and weightlifting. Cyclist <a href="Maureen%20Kaila%20Vergara">Maureen Kaila Vergara</a> finished fifth, only six points off of the podium, in the first Women's Point Race to be contested at an Olympics. <a href="Judoka">Judoka</a> <a href="Juan%20Vargas%20%28judoka%29">Juan Vargas</a> was selected to carry his nation's flag during the opening ceremony.
2000 Sydney.
El Salvador sent eight athletes to the <a href="2000%20Summer%20Olympics">2000 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>, <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. They competed in seven sports: athletics, archery, cycling, judo, shooting, swimming, and weightlifting. Weightlifter <a href="Eva%20Dimas">Eva Dimas</a> was chosen to carry her nation's flag during the opening ceremony.
2004 Athens.
Seven athletes were sent to represent El Salvador at the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Athens">Athens</a>, <a href="Greece">Greece</a>. The athletes participated in seven sports: athletics, archery, cycling, shooting, swimming, and weightlifting. Cyclist <a href="Evelyn%20Garc%C3%ADa">Evelyn García</a> was chosen to carry her nation's flag during the opening ceremony.
2008 Beijing.
El Salvador competed in more sports at the <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a>, <a href="China">China</a>, than at any other games in their history. Eleven athletes competed in nine sports: athletics, cycling, judo, rowing, shooting, swimming, tennis, weightlifting, and wrestling. Pistol shooter <a href="Luisa%20Maida">Luisa Maida</a> finished in eighth place in the Women's Sporting Pistol (25 meters), only 15.2 points away from medaling. Weightlifter Eva Dimas, who also carried the flag in 2000, was selected to carry her nation's flag during the opening ceremony.
2012 London.
Ten Salvadorian athletes were sent to represent their nation at the <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="London">London</a>, <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>. The nation had representation in seven sports: athletics, rowing, swimming, cycling, judo, shooting, and weightlifting. Cyclist Evelyn García, who also carried the flag in 2004, was selected to carry her nation's flag during the opening ceremony.
